title: BoE sends mixed messages as it struggles to contain pension crisis
text:
Good evening

“Lessons must be learned” was the Bank of England's verdict today on the pensions crisis that has sparked unprecedented interventions in government bond markets.

The presciently-timed quarterly update from its financial policy committee came as the sell-off in UK government bonds accelerated, sending long-term borrowing costs higher. The market moves came after the Bank reiterated plans to halt its emergency gilt-buying scheme this Friday. The FT had reported earlier that BoE officials had briefed lenders in private that it might extend the deadline.

The central bank has been trying to contain the fallout from chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng's package of unfunded tax cuts, which rocked sterling and the gilt market and triggered a liquidity crisis among pension funds.

As the FT Editorial Board notes, the BoE, left in the invidious position of trying to clean up someone else's mess, can only respond with a sticking plaster. Rowing back the government's proposed tax cuts would be far more effective, it argues. Huw Pill, the BoE's chief economist, warned today that a big change in interest rates was a likely response to the government's plans.

But until the chancellor unveils the details of his fiscal plan (on Halloween — hold the jokes about spooking the markets, please) it is unclear where he might find the £60bn (according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies) needed to stabilise the country's finances. Cuts in overseas aid are one possibility but Truss reiterated in parliament today that she would not cut public spending.

Even without the problems sparked by the “mini” Budget, there was another reminder this morning that the economic fundamentals remain challenging. GDP data for August showed that the economy unexpectedly shrank, suggesting the country may already be in recession.

The data also revealed that the UK trade deficit was at its widest since records began in 1997. And while many of the country's problems are shared with the rest of the world, the IMF said yesterday that high inflation would last longer in the UK than in similar economies.

Truss's mantra is “growth, growth, growth”, but Sarah O'Connor argues that most people, faced with crippling rises in the cost of living, haven't a clue what this means.

“Nobody,” O'Connor writes in her latest column, “is standing outside Downing Street with a megaphone chanting ‘What do we want? 2.5 per cent annual GDP growth. When do we want it? Over the medium term.'”

The “mini” Budget, she adds, “worsened the parts of the economy that people understand and care about, in pursuit of a target people don't understand and don't care about.”

Need to know: the economy

The IMF warned that the world was facing its “darkest hour” with threats to growth and financial stability. It urged governments to rein in spending or risk undermining the confidence of bond market investors.

Chief economics commentator Martin Wolf sums up the downside risks for the global economy and suggests what can, and should be done.

Latest for the UK and Europe

In better news for the UK, unemployment is now at its lowest since 1974, albeit as long-term sickness keeps more older workers out of the labour market. Rising living costs mean real-terms earnings have fallen at near-record rates.

A parliamentary report said the UK would miss its net zero target without serious changes in how people eat, travel and live and that the government's climate plan places “too great a reliance on undeveloped technologies.”

Germany slashed its growth forecasts for the next two years, warning that the energy crisis would push Europe's largest economy into recession next year. It is now expected to shrink 0.4 per cent next year after growth of 1.4 per cent this year.

Global latest

US president Joe Biden said Saudi Arabia would face “consequences” for its decision to cut oil production last week. He also received new warnings of a US recession from JPMorgan chief Jamie Dimon and the S&P group.

Gloom is permeating the property sector across the world. In the US, rate rises have squashed home sales and in China the crisis threatens to overshadow the hoopla of the Communist party congress this weekend.

A deepening economic crisis in Argentina is driving thousands to emigrate for the first time in generations. A popular route is Buenos Aires to Barcelona, aka “BA on the Med”.

Need to know: business

Ecommerce is having a tough time after its golden period during the pandemic. Amazon is holding an additional “Prime Day” shopping event in a year to revive flagging sales, while grocery delivery app Getir is in talks to take over its heavily lossmaking rival Gorillas.

Tough times too for “gig economy” companies such as Uber, whose shares slid after the US proposed a new test to determine whether workers were employees or independent contractors.

Our Big Read offers some lessons on corporate ethics embodied in the battle between Ben & Jerry's and its parent Unilever over Israel.

Microchips from Japanese-owned, UK-based Arm can be found in almost every smartphone and myriad electronic devices but its plans to go public have set off a scrap between investors, governments and rivals. Watch our new film.

The World of Work

“Here they come! Complaining about coming into work to do what is their actual job! Wanting to stay at home in their pyjamas and take all their client meetings on Zoom! These people with their self-care and their mental health . . . Who do they think they are? Next thing they will be wanting paid holidays.” Viv Groskop explores the new breed of toxic worker.

“Work and business shows are the fourth most popular category of podcast, just behind arts and ahead of religion and spirituality. Make of that what you will,” says Working It host Isabel Berwick. This week she talks to the people behind some of the world's best to discuss the future of work and the post-Covid workplace.

Some good news.

The Grand Title winner of the National History Museum's Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition is Karine Aigner's “The Big Buzz”, which captures the flurry of activity as cactus bees compete to mate with a female. Sugandhi Gadadhar, wildlife film-maker and judge, said: “In today's world, where we struggle to grab the attention of the policymakers towards even big mammals, this image helps in bringing the spotlight to one of nature's most important creatures.”
